thread.title: Cardinals no longer control own destiny in Southland Conference
thread.title_full: Cardinals no longer control own destiny in Southland Conference

author: Danny Shapiro
title: Cardinals no longer control own destiny in Southland Conference
text:
Cardinals no longer control own destiny in Southland Conference Danny Shapir , Beaumont Enterprise Updated 11:31 am, Monday, October 19, 2015 Image 1 of / 2 Close Image 1 of 2 Duncan McVey, 88, looks to make the catch during the game between the Lamar Cardinals and the Northwestern State Demons at Turpin Stadium in Natchitoches, LA, Saturday, October 17th, 2015 - photo provided by Kyle Ezell Duncan McVey, 88, looks to make the catch during the game between the Lamar Cardinals and the Northwestern State Demons at Turpin Stadium in Natchitoches, LA, Saturday, October 17th, 2015 - photo provided by ... more Image 2 of 2 Kade Harrington passes the ball during the game between the Lamar Cardinals and the Northwestern State Demons at Turpin Stadium in Natchitoches, LA, Saturday, October 17th, 2015 - photo provided by Kyle Ezell Kade Harrington passes the ball during the game between the Lamar Cardinals and the Northwestern State Demons at Turpin Stadium in Natchitoches, LA, Saturday, October 17th, 2015 - photo provided by Kyle Ezell Cardinals no longer control own destiny in Southland Conference 1 / 2 Back to Gallery 
There was an electricity in the air three weeks ago in Hammond, Louisiana, after Lamar narrowly lost 30-27 to defending Southland Conference champion Southeastern Louisiana. 
Cardinals coach Ray Woodard and his players were outwardly optimistic and upbeat despite the loss, because they had played well for a third consecutive week on the road against a quality opponent. 
But most importantly, because they still controlled their fate in the race for the conference championship. 
Following Saturday's disappointing 48-35 loss in Natchitoches, Louisiana, to previously-winless Northwestern State, that is no longer the case. 
And that positive energy is gone. 
There was a stale feeling of disappointment outside the Lamar locker room postgame as the Cardinals dropped to 3-3 overall and 2-2 in the Southland, which moved them into a fourth-place tie in the conference. 
RELATED: Slow start dooms Cardinals vs. Northwestern State 
"Man, it's still fresh and (this loss) hurts so much right now," Cardinals senior quarterback Joe Minden said. "We were in the driver's seat to win the conference and now we need a lot of help to get back there." 
The Cardinals entered Saturday one game behind McNeese State and Central Arkansas and tied with Sam Houston State and Southeastern Louisiana in the loss column before the loss to the Demons. 
McNeese State beat Central Arkansas, whom the Cardinals will play host to Saturday, 28-13 and Southeastern Louisiana fell at home to Stephen F. Austin 28-27. 
Lamar owned the tiebreaker over Sam Houston State after defeating them 49-46 in Week 3, so a win over the Demons would have put the Cardinals into a second place tie with Central Arkansas. 
Instead, Woodard's Cardinals are going to need luck, and no more stale performances like Saturday against the Demons, to regain their confidence and conference title aspirations. 
"We let one go against Northwestern State and that's on me," Woodard said. "We don't control our destiny anymore. For the most part, we were outcoached and outplayed." 
RELATED: Cardinals defense on brink of complete game 
It was Lamar's worst showing of the season and it came against — at least record wise — the worse team in the conference. 
"All losses hurt," Cardinals running back Kade Harrington said. "But we really missed an opportunity. We came out a little flat and they jumped on us." 
Harrington believes the Cardinals still have a chance of reaching its goals, but knows the loss to the Demons was a major setback. 
"We just have to bounce back," Harrington said. "We're all here to win and that's all that matters. So that's what we're going to have to do the rest of the way."
